Class Breakout

  • java.lang.Object
    • java.awt.Component
      • java.awt.Container

          • java.applet.Applet

              • acm.program.Program
                • acm.program.GraphicsProgram
                  • Breakout
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    acm.io.IOModel, java.awt.event.ActionListener, java.awt.event.KeyListener, java.awt.event.MouseListener, java.awt.event.MouseMotionListener, java.awt.image.ImageObserver, java.awt.MenuContainer, java.io.Serializable, java.lang.Runnable, java.util.EventListener, javax.accessibility.Accessible, javax.swing.RootPaneContainer

    public class Breakout
extends acm.program.GraphicsProgram
    A standard breakout game that consist of 100 bricks layed out in 10 bricks per row. The aim is for the player to use the paddle, that is tracked by the mouse on x-axis, to reflect the ball that is fired upon it and destroy all the blocks using it. To start, the playser simply has to left click the mouse.
    Author:
    Kosta
    See Also:
    Serialized Form

    • Method Summary

      Methods 
      Modifier and Type Method and Description
      void anotherTry()
      Reduces the amount of tries left by 1 every time it is envoked then invokes "play()" to continue playing
      void brickRow(int numRows)
      Creates a column of bricks.
      void checkObjectCollision()
      Checks for the collisions that the ball makes with other objects (paddle and bricks) if colliding with paddle, then the vertical velocity is reversed (the ball is reflected) otherwise, the ball will be checked for collision with bricks, at which point the ball will be reflected again, however the brick that was touched will be removed also, the brick counted will be decremented by 1 and a check for 0 bricks (checkWin()) will be called
      void checkWallCollision()
      Checks for collisions in any of the 4 walls.
      void checkWin()
      Checks if all the bricks have been eliminated from the playing field.
      acm.graphics.GObject getCollidingObject()
      4 points of possible collision are initialised.
      void makeBall()
      Creates a ball that is used to destroy the bricks in the game
      void mouseMoved(java.awt.event.MouseEvent e)
      Called to make the paddle foollow the x-axis of the mouse includes the fixes for the paddle going off the screen
      void paddle()
      Creates the paddle that follows the x-axis of the mouse and is fixed on the y-coordinate seen in PADDLE_Y_OFFSET
      void play()
      at first, creates a label that tells the user the click the mouse button to play afterwards, removes that label, and creates a fully functioning ball that is used to break the bricks
      void run()
      Runs the Breakout program.
      void setup()
      creates the playing field, the paddle and the set of bricks required for the game

    • Method Detail

      • run

        public void run()
        Runs the Breakout program.
        Specified by:
        run in interface java.lang.Runnable
        Overrides:
        run in class acm.program.GraphicsProgram

      • setup

        public void setup()
        creates the playing field, the paddle and the set of bricks required for the game

      • play

        public void play()
        at first, creates a label that tells the user the click the mouse button to play afterwards, removes that label, and creates a fully functioning ball that is used to break the bricks

      • makeBall

        public void makeBall()
        Creates a ball that is used to destroy the bricks in the game

      • checkWallCollision

        public void checkWallCollision()
        Checks for collisions in any of the 4 walls. Note: if the ball collides with the bottom wall, then "anotherTry()" method is called

      • checkWin

        public void checkWin()
        Checks if all the bricks have been eliminated from the playing field. When that happens, removes the ball and adds the label exclaiming to the user that he/she won.

      • anotherTry

        public void anotherTry()
        Reduces the amount of tries left by 1 every time it is envoked then invokes "play()" to continue playing

      • checkObjectCollision

        public void checkObjectCollision()
        Checks for the collisions that the ball makes with other objects (paddle and bricks) if colliding with paddle, then the vertical velocity is reversed (the ball is reflected) otherwise, the ball will be checked for collision with bricks, at which point the ball will be reflected again, however the brick that was touched will be removed also, the brick counted will be decremented by 1 and a check for 0 bricks (checkWin()) will be called
        See Also:
        getCollidingObject()

      • getCollidingObject

        public acm.graphics.GObject getCollidingObject()
        4 points of possible collision are initialised. These are located on the corners of the bounding square of the ball. Then every object is checked one after the other for collision, if no collisions present, then the return is null, otherwise, the object that the ball collided with is retured

      • paddle

        public void paddle()
        Creates the paddle that follows the x-axis of the mouse and is fixed on the y-coordinate seen in PADDLE_Y_OFFSET

      • mouseMoved

        public void mouseMoved(java.awt.event.MouseEvent e)
        Called to make the paddle foollow the x-axis of the mouse includes the fixes for the paddle going off the screen
        Specified by:
        mouseMoved in interface java.awt.event.MouseMotionListener
        Overrides:
        mouseMoved in class acm.program.Program

      • brickRow

        public void brickRow(int numRows)
        Creates a column of bricks. uses a loop that adds a new brick to the canvas from top to bottom taking into the account the initial y-offest that is seen in BRICK_Y_OFFSET
